textContent:
A lot of the server premise stands on the supposed ability of the client to handle unit reactions to one another independently of factions.

How would this work, on a practical level? Like onions, it's composed of layers.

Baseline, in an interaction between two units with different reactions to each other, the most hostile applies. If one thinks the other is friendly, but the other one is hostile, then the reaction for both is hostile.

The order of the layers is determined by each player and can be changed anytime. But the default is:

1. Your class reaction (if the class has one). Then,
2. (Maybe?) Your origin story reaction. Then,
3. Your guild reaction (if you have one). Lastly,
4. Your own reaction (if you decide to have one)
5. Your vows (if you have them). This layer cannot be changed. (Ex: Paladins are always hostile to Demons, even if their guild wants them to change, as they vowed it. Druids are always friendly to Docile Beasts...). Locks the previous layer (Personal) from input.

At any time, a player may open their Reaction panel. This panel includes the following sections: 
1. List of all creature factions, with the ability of changing your personal reaction to them. If you are a qualified guild officer, you can also change the guild reaction to said group.
2. Your currently selected unit, with the ability to see all of its reaction layers and change your personal or guild (if qualified) reaction to it.
3. A list of all your reactions, displayed in a manner that allows you to see which layer is responsible for the reaction. Displays all reactions that are mentioned in any way in any of your layers (as otherwise, it's just hostile). It's colored red and displays a warning for when the reactions are not reciprocal.
Examples for a Druid:
1. Rangers Pack: Class: Friendly -> Guild: Unfriendly -> Personal: Friendly. This tells a story of how the druid still gets along with the faction regardless of their guild hostility.
2. Poacher's Club: Class: Hostile -> Guild -> Friendly -> Vow: Hostile. A story of how a druid can never be on good terms with poachers.
3. Guild N2: Guild: Friendly. Druid gets along with this other guild.
4. Master Bekele: Personal: Friendly
5. Sark'od the Destroyer: Personal: Friendly (NOT RECIPROCAL)


This system is not exclusive to players. Different units or factions can change their reactions to other factions, guilds or specific players or units. This is based on certain conditions being met. An encounter, event, a GM interaction, etc.
